thread.title_full: U.S. Wins Presidents Cup in Final-Hole Thriller - WSJ

author: Alastair Gale
title: U.S. Wins Presidents Cup in Final-Hole Thriller
text:
1 COMMENTS INCHEON, South Korea—The U.S. beat an international team in golf’s Presidents Cup, as they normally do, but this year’s tournament had something it usually lacks: gripping drama.
Bill Haas, son of team captain Jay Haas, sealed the win on the final hole of the last singles match on Sunday as opponent Bae Sang-moon of South Korea mistimed a chip to the green, leaving it short and disappointing a big home crowd.
After a long run of tournaments featuring hefty U.S. wins, the final score was 15.5-14.5—the tightest margin of victory in 10 years and the first time the competition has been won on the final hole.
Jay Haas fought back tears after his son took the winning point. “I couldn’t even have dreamt this,” he said on the 18th green of the Jack Nicklaus Golf Club Korea, in Incheon.
The U.S. extended its winning streak to six and now has a record of nine wins, one draw and one defeat since the competition began in 1994.
In some ways it was also a victory for Nick Price, captain of the team of non-European international players. For years, Price called for the tournament to be shortened to make it a closer battle. This year, the total number of matches was reduced to 30 from 34 .
“This is what the Presidents Cup needed. There’s no doubt,” he said after the defeat.
Each session, from Friday afternoon through to the end of the tournament, finished with only one point separating the teams.
At one stage on Sunday afternoon it looked as though the International team was on a winning surge, as Indian Anirban Lahiri lined up a 4-foot putt on the final green, at a point when other matches were swinging against the U.S. However, Lahiri’s putt lipped out, surrendering a point and the momentum back to the U.S.
ENLARGE The International team’s Bae Sang-moon reacts after a bad pitch shot on the 18h hole in his Presidents Cup match against Bill Haas of the U.S. on Sunday. Photo: Getty Images Bae, who will start his compulsory two-year military service soon, sank to his haunches and put his head in his hands after he fluffed his final approach shot. But after winning 2.5 points for the team, he said he was eager for another opportunity to play in the tournament.
“It’s OK, it’s OK,” the crowd chanted to him as he finished the final hole.
U.S. veteran Phil Mickelson justified his selection as a captain’s pick with three wins and a draw, making him joint top scorer for the team with 2015 British Open winner Zach Johnson. South African Branden Grace led the International team with a perfect record of five wins—only the fifth player in competition history to achieve the feat.
An anticipated matchup between the world’s top two ranked players—Jordan Spieth of the U.S. and Jason Day of Australia—didn’t happen, and both players lost their singles matches to other opponents.
The next edition of the tournament will be held at Liberty National, in New Jersey, starting in Sept. 2017. The Ryder Cup—the better known golf face-off between the U.S. and Team Europe—is scheduled to start in late Sept. next year, at the Hazeltine course in Minnesota.
While the Presidents Cup is likely to remain the less anticipated of the two competitions, players and coaches from both sides agreed this year’s tight battle has breathed new life into the tournament.
“They (they players) have got some fire to go on because it got so close,” said Price.
